answers.answer: The following types of consultations are included in the primary medical assistance: consultation for monitoring the evolution of pregnancy and labor, which involves supervision in the first quarter, monthly monitoring from the 3rd month to the 7th month, twice-monthly monitoring from the 7th month to the 9th month, and postpartum monitoring at home. Exclusive breastfeeding promotion up to the age of six months and continued until at least twelve months is also encouraged. Additionally, prenatal tests such as HIV, Hepatitis B and C are suggested for the pregnant woman. Two additional diagnostic and therapeutic services are available, including supervision during labor and an unplanned delivery.

answers.answer: The duration of prenatal check-ups varies throughout the entire pregnancy. During the first trimester (up to the seventh week), there are three types of consultations: one primary medical consultation, followed by monthly visits from the third month onwards, and then bi-monthly visits starting from the seventh month up until the ninth month. After delivery, patients receive additional postnatal care including home monitoring sessions. Additionally, the basic package provides exclusive breastfeeding promotion until the age of six months and encourages continued feeding till at least twelve months old. Furthermore, HIV, Hepatitis of viral etiology with viruses B & C, and other required paraclinical tests are conducted on the mother-to-be. Lastly, the basic package offers two diagnostic and therapeutic medical services which include supervising labor without giving birth and an unanticipated birth, both of which may be performed by the family physician.

answers.answer: Yes, certain conditions can be detected during both the second and first trimesters of pregnancy through obstetrical ultrasounds. answers.answer: The supervision of a normal pregnancy covers one consultation for each trimester of pregnancy and a consultation in the first trimester after birth. It includes various medical services such as obstetrics-gynecology specialist consultations, complete blood count, determination of the ABO blood group in pregnant women, determination of the Rh blood group in pregnant women, serum urea, serum uric acid, serum creatinine, blood glucose, TGP, TGO, TSH, complete examination of urine (summary + sediment), VDRL or RPR, HIV testing in pregnant women, evaluation of pregnant women for infections at risk for pregnancy (such as rubella, toxoplasmosis, CMV infection, hepatitis B and C), vaginal discharge, cervical-vaginal cytological exam, fetal biometry, Group B Streptococcus detection, confirmation ultrasound and pregnancy viability.
